title: Melbourne Cup stolen by thugs from Houdini's cafè è cucina
text:
A desperate call for help has been made after the 2017 Melbourne Cup was stolen from a cafe.

The trophy had been at Houdini’s cafè è cucina in Melbourne's Digger’s Rest when it was taken on Saturday night.

Melbourne Cup trophies are worth up to $150,000.

The stolen trophy was a replica of the original as there were multiple owners, but still holds significant sentimental value to the owner.

The cup's owner Mark Ruff told Daily Mail Australia he had been left devastated after discovering the trophy was snatched.

The trophy had been at Houdini’s cafè è cucina in Melbourne's Digger’s Rest when it was taken on Saturday night. Aussie model Rachael Finch is pictured with trophy in 2017

Restaurant owners have urged for anyone with information on its whereabouts to get in touch immediately

He said it wasn't about the monetary value, which he assumed wouldn't be very much.

'It's mainly the sentimental value, to win a Melbourne Cup is pretty special and for some grub to steal it, it's just not a good feeling,' he said.

Mr Ruff was part owner of the horse Rekindling, who won the 2017 Melbourne Cup.

Lloyd Williams owns the actual Melbourne Cup, while the other part-owners each have replicas.

Mr Ruff had chosen to display the cup in the local restaurant near his home as he had wanted to share it with the community and wanted to give others the chance to take a picture with it.

'It's better than keeping it in our living room.'

The thieves ransacked the cafe between 11.30pm on Saturday and 10.30am on Sunday, according to police.

They stole the cash register, cash and the 2017 Melbourne Cup.

Jockey Corey Brown kisses the Melbourne Cup after winning race 7, the Emirates Melbourne Cup on Rekindling on Melbourne Cup Day at Flemington Racecourse on November 7, 2017

The restaurant owner has urged for anyone with information on its whereabouts to get in touch immediately.

'We appreciate any information of its whereabouts or if anyone has seen or heard anything to contact us, let’s get the cup back to its rightful owner,' they posted on Facebook.

Victoria Police are investigating the incident.

Anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000
